text: um so thank you so much for the introduction my name is Christiana skullman and I'm the director of usil change.org um and thank you so much for

are in the world and it's been an inspiring ride and I'm happy to share some of those stories with you guys today so um chain or as you just got a
little bit of briefing on has grown quite large since it was founded in 2007
we have over 1.2 million visitors daily and um currently are sitting at around 77 78 million users globally um and I'm

our mission um is to empower anyone anywhere to create the change in the
world that they hope to see um we are currently the world's largest petition platform there are plenty of other places you can go on the internet to
start petitions but we are the one that Garners the most users and the most individual visits um and sometimes this
change can be as small as asking a local town to put in a stop sign on a sidewalk
um or to put in a stoplight um at a busy intersection or it can be as big as
dozens of countries around the world starting petitions asking their head of state or the Nobel committee to nominate
and um Award malalo with the Nobel Peace Prize um I was actually really excited

this is a picture of Jen Tyrell who was a boy scouts den leader which is
essentially like the leader of a troop for Boy Scouts um and she was kicked out and asked to resign because she's gay
and when she when that happened to her she actually turned to change that org and started a petition sharing her story
with users explaining that she felt like she had been discriminated against and she just wanted to be a part of her son's life and didn't see why it was
fair or why it was okay that she was being asked to leave and not participate um in this activity with her family um
simply because of her orientation and her petition her individual petition got over $300,000
signatures at the time of this delivery where the picture is from it had about 300,000 but I think it's up to 600,000 now and it really sparked an incredible
movement in the United States um the Boy Scouts is I think folks may be familiar with is one of the sort of it's an I
would consider to be an Antiquated institution it's not one that is likely to be receptive to outside influence um
they are very publicly aligned with conservative and religious values and have public opinions on homosexuality
and so they're not a likely candidate to say yes you're right we're discriminating against you and we're going to change um but her story brought
forth many many other stories of people who were involved in the Boy Scouts um specifically one kid who was 18 years
old his name was Ryan Anderson and he was denied his Eagle Scout specifically because he was gay and his mother after
hearing about Jennifer Tyrell started a petition um specifically calling on the Boy Scouts to award her son his Eagle
Award and it got over a million signatures he got incredible media from this attention um it sparked a movement
of other Scouts stepping forward and identifying as being gay and being kicked out of their troops for the same reason um and because of that um this
like a really incredibly coordinated campaign over eight months later the Boy Scouts announced in like a very historic
decision that they were no longer going to discriminate against gay Scouts and that they were going to allow them to participate in the Boy Scouts of America
organization um which is pretty incredible um unfortunately for Jen though she is still waiting for them to
allow gay parents um many people think that it's just a matter of time um but she is still not allowed to participate
in the Boy Scouts with her son um but I'm telling her story because this is a
really important example of how one person's story on and using the our
platform on change.org has helped spark a national movement and made some really significant change in a organization
that was expected to sort of be that was considered sort of unchangeable um this is a picture of
Matt Zeller and he is a US Army veteran who served in Iraq and Afghanistan and
he worked really closely with the man who's pictured to his left whose name is um Janice shinari who was his
interpreter while he was in Afghanistan and um I've seen interviews of Matt and
he just has so much emotion and deep connection to Janice and says that without him and his help um as a
interpreter in Afghanistan that he would have died and that many their their mission would have been unsuccessful and their deployment would have been a lot
more dangerous than it was um but unfortunately for or interpreters who are allied with American troops um in
different countries they're often considered enemies of the state or combatants of the um sorry enemies of
the um oppositional forces and so when this specific deployment left and um
Janice was no longer associated with the United States military he was considered an enemy of the Taliban and when Matt
came back to the United States Janice contacted him and said I'm fearing for my life I applied for United States visa
and I've been to the Embassy in cabul several times and I don't think my Visa application is going to go anywhere and
I don't think that anyone is hearing me and I'm going to die like I'm receiving death threats I cannot leave my house
the Taliban is going to kill me they're going to kill other interpreters as well it's very dangerous for people to be interpreters associated with United
States troops so Matt turned to change.org and started a petition specifically asking for the embassy to
FastTrack his visa and he got over 113,000 signatures he got a lot of media
attention once his petition started gaining Steam and this also brought forth an entire like crop of other
stories and petitions from other veterans or active service members who had also worked with interpreters and
other countries who um who were also facing similar challenges to Janice um in their home countries and Janice's
Visa ended up being approved which is absolutely incredible and they had a very tearful and emotional reuniting um

sent over 500 in this year we've sent over 550 million emails Alone um and

Target our audiences um and they included causes like animals uh criminal

this is a petition that was started by a young woman named Alexandra and she is a
survivor of sexual assault while she was at Yale um and the school reviews to refused to investigate her
assault so before we got machine learning and targeting capabilities we had a really tough time with this
campaign um as I mentioned earlier and as I shared with with you all we really
pride ourselves on putting the petition starter story front and center and all the work that we do um that's just a
